author: aharon
title: CA Guidelines Joint Drafting
description: Adjusting and agreeing on the community's roles and responsibilities set out in the guidelines lacks suitable tooling and processes.

f6_assessments.q0: The proposal is well aligned with the challenge. It correctly identifies that one of the biggest and most demanding elements of (V)CAs' work is the ongoing process of discussion and revision of the process itself, and that there is an issue with having so many locations where discussions take place. A tool that helps organise and document these discussions, while also keeping them decentralised and inclusive/participatory, would significantly improve both (V)CAs' work and (V)CA resources.
f6_assessments.q1: On the positive side, the prototype of the Consenz tool is already in use and working well, so it seems likely it could be implemented for this use; also, the proposal demonstrates a good understanding of how the Catalyst community works, which is crucial for making something like this feasible. In particular, the risk assessment accurately identifies one of the key potential problems in getting new tools adopted in Catalyst, i.e. what could be called "platform fatigue" and potential low participation. The idea of mitigating this with co-design sessions is basically sound; but the problem is that this co-design process is quite undercosted, which suggests to me, as a community engagement worker myself, that the work involved in doing this effectively has been underestimated or not fully understood. Promoting the co-design sessions across the community so as to engage more than the "usual voices", skilled facilitation of the sessions, documenting the sessions and making sure that comments and ideas are accurately and transparently recorded, and giving some kind of feedback after the sessions with information about the outcomes/results or explaining how you have responded to the issues raised so that people know they were heard, should cost considerably more than $160 per session. In other words, the time and work needed for an effective co-design session is considerably more then just the 2 hours of the session itself; and the fact that this is not planned for, described, or budgeted for is a concern. The rest of the budget seems ok (only 3 webinars to onboard such a big community as CAs is maybe a little ambitious, but this is probably mitigated by having an ongoing "tech support" call centre to give support outside of the webinars) but the co-design sessions feel so crucial to the feasibility of the proposal that, since they don't feel solid, I can't feel sure the proposal would be implemented in a meaningful way. I feel there's a danger that levels of community engagement and co-design would be cursory and un-inclusive, and that this would mean that the solution wouldn't be widely understood or adopted by CAs. Whilst this would not prevent the proposal being "implemented" in the sense that Consenz could be offered as a tool for CAs to use, the core of what would make this proposal work seems to be the question of co-design to promote actual engagement. Since this co-design process is fundamentally under-resourced, then I feel that feasibility is questionable.  I'd also like to see some information on what kind of "reset" or adjustments would be done if the mid-term (3 month) milestones are not reached, for example if uptake or user satisfaction is low after 3 months.
f6_assessments.q2: Audit metrics are clear and appropriate, and it's good that they include targets, and that they address not only the uptake (i.e. numbers registered to use Consenz) but also satisfaction levels, and actual usage (numbers of documents created). However, I'd ideally like to see some information on how satisfaction levels/positive feedback from users will actually be collected/measured, in order to be able to assess that.

f6_assessments.q0: This is a well aligned proposal with a promising deliverable that will be eagerly tested and hopefully adopted by the CA community.  While some improvement projects (these are projects meant to bring positive change to the "plumbing" of Catalyst QA process) for CAs end up deep in the weeds of analysis and introspection, many, many more than that develop quickly on documents, or arise from teamwork that has a need to "get it on paper"....where the efforts often fizzle out.  Among the things the process is missing is a method to achieve consensus around proposed changes and solutions, and often this consensus is all that stands between a proposed solution and the "finalization" required to push it out to those who would execute it.  This tool, which is a funded development of Fund7, seeks to combine some of the more insightful paradigms for achieving productive consensus (liquid democracy, etc) with a document editing and finalizing protocol to move projects to completion via mini consensus around elements of the documents.  Add in the ability to further refine the tool to capture communication channels like telegram and discord, and two of the critical roadblocks to CA improvement work will be solved.
f6_assessments.q1: The tool is already well under way in development, and the team has smartly forked a development branch of it to fully embrace input from the CA/vCA community.  Within a 3 month or so window they expect to roll out an MVP version of the tool for the CAs, where they can receive feedback on the UI/UX and ways to align it perfectly with the work that CAs are trying to do.  It is likely that the more input they get, the better and faster the tool will iterate.  Their budget is a steal in the sub-$10k range, and it is distributed well across management and onboarding, with a healthy 50%+ for the development side.  Because the tool itself is being funded from previous proposals, this budget represents just the CA specific build out and use case.  The teams experience across Catalyst, and especially as CAs themselves means they already have critical insight into what is a requirement, as well as the minimum MVP needed to work for CAs.  After that, the rest should just be frosting.  In fact, looking at their targeted "satisfaction" rate of 70%...that looks like rookie numbers.  100%. (But I guess you can't please everyone...lets go with 99% here.)
f6_assessments.q2: The provided road map is light on details, and could likely be moved forward 4-6 weeks through the first phase (I personally think there will be plenty of feedback from the community, so no need to assign extra time here), but still manages to convey all the major milestones the project requires.  A good amount of time is dedicated to the final stage, which is onboarding, and I expect that much of that is actually going to be taken out of their hands by engaged CAs who want to onboard collaborators to their initiatives, so there is a high likelihood that this project screams through its phases to completion.  The audit points in that scenario are less relevant, but there are plenty of milestones to report when the progress reports come due, with the main ones being CA engagement early, and onboarded CAs to the tool late.  And as far as the community keeping track of the proposal...?  Yeah, there will be a lot of beady little CA eyes tracking this one through the Catalyst jungle.  No worries there.

f6_assessments.q0:
Consenz is a consensus / agreements building platform previously funded in Fund7 that allows participants to take an active role in discussion and editing documents. The prototype has been in development even before Catalyst funding and has been used by several groups for various purposes, for instance (1) schools developing teaching guidelines, (2) demands created by NGOs / spontaneous protest grous or (3) NGO - municipality interaction for climate plans. 

Right now the team behind Consenz are proposing the tool as a mechanism for the Catalyst community to collaborate more efficiently in drafting guidelines for CAs and VCAs, reducing the work needs of IOG for coordination purposes. For this they would need to build incremental updates to their platform - hence the funding request.

This being an incremental efficiency change and fully aligned with the challenge of making CAs and VCAs lives easier, I fully support this proposal and I think it is worth voting for.
f6_assessments.q1:
There is an existing and solid team behind Consenz, so it has excellent chances of implementing it, especially considering the fact that it had received funds in F7 and that a working product is already live, so only small additions are necessary. 

The overall budget is modest, with 50% going towards code implementation and content management / webinars / training sessions sharing rather equally the rest.  

Time-wise, implementation will happen on the MVP version of Consenz previously funded in F7. It would have been a great addition if useful details regarding the timeline were introduced in this proposal too, for clarity and making sure that the team truly stands behind its timelines. But roughly 16 weeks shall be necessary for development 

Overall a fair job done by the Consenz team in explaining how the project would proceed, perhaps with a better explanation and accountability of their deadlines.
f6_assessments.q2:
How will they measure their success? Through (1) % of the CA telegram group members registered to Consenz, (2) % of the participants will express positive feedback about the use of Consnez and (3) number of documents created by the community on the platform. 

Being a collaborative tool that will have immediate and visible impacts throughout the community, especially for CAs, I judge it will be fairly easy to see how the community received the new documents and whether increased transparency / clarity of guidelines will happen (also) due to the new tool, vs. the “old ways” of drafting the guidelines. 

The proposal is a welcomed addition to the ecosystem and it won’t be difficult to gauge its success once implemented. Go for it!

f6_assessments.q0:
This is a great proposal that focuses on using Consenz: agreements building platform to define the CA work and draft clear guidelines in a collaborative, focused, and transparent way. Concerning impact, some issues that should be noted are as follow:
Firstly, the proposers define a suitable problem within the challenge which needs to be solved, explain it in detail with rationale. They demonstrate a certain deep understanding of the field they are discussing. The problem raised shows the authenticity and urgency to be solved in order to achieve the goals of the challenge in particular and the entire ecosystem in general. In addition, the proposed solution is clearly defined. It shows the possibility of adding value to the Cardano ecosystem with a clear expected impact in short term and long term. Besides, the proposer also defines the possibility of scaling to address future challenges.
In conclusion, I strongly agree with the impact of this proposal.
f6_assessments.q1:
Regarding feasibility, there are some issues that should be noted, including:
First of all, this team profile is clearly described, show suitable skill, experiences for implementation, with reference/proof (documents/links,...) for verifying. In addition, as I know, this team/proposer has a proposal funded in the prior fund. This proposal's goal is clear and realistic supported by convincing reasons, along with a specific roadmap, some logical, measurable KPIs/metrics, and a budget breakdown for assessing the detail of the implementation process. Additionally, the risk is clearly defined with some mitigation as well as some further explanation of how performance that mitigation would be; This shows that the proposer has fully looked at and realistic vision of what could happen during the implementation of this proposal. 
Therefore, based on the provided information, I strongly agree with this proposal's feasibility
f6_assessments.q2:
Regarding this proposal's auditability, there are some issues that should be noted, including:
First of all, as can be seen, this team profile is clearly described, with reference/proof (documents/links,...) for confirmation. Secondly, the roadmap is described enough for understanding. For measuring the success of this proposal, the proposer(s) choose some measurable KPI/metrics, including: (i) > 35% of the CA telegram group members registered to consenz; (ii) > 70% of the participants will express positive feedback about the use of consnez; (iii) > 3 documents created by the community on consenz platform. This proposal's budget has provided with clear cost items structure and understandable explanations of calculation base [number of employees, number of working hours, labor price,...].
Based on the provided information, I strongly agree with this proposal's auditability

f6_assessments.q0:
This proposal is a step forward on the way to Catalyst decentralization, as it aims at defining a process where the community would be able to collectively define roles and responsibilities in Project Catalyst (and easier IOG work in this area). It focuses on the CA role, but this proposal could be extended in future funds to other roles like VCa for example.
Being a CA myself, and following telegram channel/zoom meetings, I confirm that the problem stated by the proposal needs to be addressed: CA role is complicated, and there are many endless debates about how rules/CA guidance should evolve.
We do not lack ideas, but the decision-making process is not clear and efficient, and agreeing is still difficult. 
This project aims at using “consenz agreement building platform”, a project funded in Fund 7 to solve this issue. I strongly agree that this proposal effectively addresses the CA Improvements challenge.
f6_assessments.q1:
The proposer has a lot of experience with all Catalyst Project, and has been successfully funded multiple times, which is obviously a good indication for the chances of success of this development. The proposal includes details about the team members, showing they gather the necessary skills for project development.
The main risk is well identified by the proposer: a situation of low participation due to many existing other platforms. The risk mitigation plan is smart and relevant.
I strongly agree that this proposal is likely to be successful.
f6_assessments.q2: First coordination meetings for CA/Vca are expected 12-16 weeks after launch. The proposal details intermediate milestones and include a budget breakdown. I miss a little bit of details in the proposal about how the progress of the development will be communicated to the community. Co-design sessions are mentioned, and I understand that progress update will be given during townhalls for example. I agree that the community will have the capacity to monitor the progress of this proposal.

f6_assessments.q0:
I understand your suggestion is to create a CA guide that is jointly drafted, edited by the CA, vCA community. The general drafting will help the information in the guide become transparent and objective, reducing the workload of the Catalyst Management Board. Comments and edits will be decentralized through the system. This is a pretty cool platform. 
However, is a CA instruction sheet that so many people draft and vote together, is it necessary? And will this really contribute to the improvement of CA quality as the instruction sheet is constantly being revised? And I see the problem that makes the CA quality is not good, not attracted many CAs, nor is it largely due to the lack of specific CA guidelines. Therefore, I think your proposal helps to improve convenience but does not actually solve the problem that Challenge posed. I think your idea would be better suited to solving other Catalyst challenges.
f6_assessments.q1:
The proposal is a continuation of a proposal approved in Fund 7, the work items required for this proposal are specifically listed, and the time required for implementation is outlined. However, I think you should write a more detailed, specific plan.
Regarding the budget, the budget has a detailed spreadsheet, specific to each work item and cost. The spreadsheet is clear and easy to understand. Reasonable cost for each work item.
Regarding the experience of the members of the development team, the experience and skills are clearly stated, suitable to perform the work items stated in the proposal. Information about experience and skills can be checked by Linkedin links attached in the proposal.
f6_assessments.q2:
The proposal offers KPIs, target indicators that the project expects to achieve after 3 months and in the first 1 year. I think you will need a lot of effort to achieve these KPIs.
One thing I haven't seen you mention in the proposal is how can the community, Catalyst assess whether your KPIs can be achieved as stated? If you have more guidance on where to check these metrics I think suggestions would be more appreciated.

solution: Use consenz: agreements building platform to define the CA work and draft clear guidelines in a collaborative, focused and transparent way
experience: Project Catalyst active member since F5. Proposer since F6. Funded proposer of F7. Also CA at F7. Founder and project manager of consenz since 2018. Partnered with ADAgov - F4, F5, F6 founded. Supported by AIM.
